name: 杨晓东
abstracts: Yang Xiaodong is a buddhologist and art historian, and assistant professor in the Department of History (Zhuhai) at Sun Yat-sen University. While he works primarily in the areas of Sinitic Buddhism, his scholarly interests are broad, encompassing the pan-Buddhist world in its entirety. More specifically, his recent research has focused on the surviving Buddhist monuments in the Sichuan basin—particularly those concerning the cult of Liu Benzun 柳本尊, and quite by serendipity, he becomes increasingly curious about the question of terminology in the translation and transformation of Buddhist technical terms. Besides being fluent in Chinese and English, he speaks Japanese and, occasionally, reads Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit and Classical Tibetan in their original forms.

name: 詹镇鹏
abstracts: As an Associate Professor in the Department of History (Zhuhai) at Sun Yat-sen University, I received my Ph.D. in History of Chinese Art from the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) and worked at the Hong Kong Maritime Museum (HKMM) in 2018-2019. My research expertise and interests include the material culture and decorative arts of late imperial China (particularly lacquer), history of collecting at the Qing imperial court, Buddhist and Daoist visual culture, as well as artistic and cultural interactions between East and West. The object-based training and working experiences led me to participate in major exhibitions held by CUHK Art Museum and HKMM. I have published over twenty articles and book reviews in peer-reviewed or internationally recognized journals, such as Late Imperial China, Religion and the Arts, Arts of Asia, Taida Journal of Art History, National Palace Museum Research Quarterly and Monthly. In 2022, I published the translated Chinese book of Dorothy Ko’s English monograph The Social Life of Inkstones: Artisans and Scholars in Early Qing China with the Commercial Press (Beijing). My current research encompasses two book projects: the material culture (production, circulation, display, storage) of imperial lacquers in the Ming and Qing courts; and the dynamic transformation and afterlife of the Qing imperial collection within and outside the Forbidden City in the 20th century.
